exercises.title: Machine Learning Fundamentals
exercises.description: Test your knowledge of basic machine learning concepts
exercises.content: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn from data.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
options: Supervised learning uses labeled data, unsupervised does not
Unsupervised learning is faster than supervised learning
Supervised learning only works with numerical data
questions.correctAnswer: Supervised learning uses labeled data, unsupervised does not
questions.explanation: Supervised learning algorithms learn from labeled training data (input-output pairs), while unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data without predefined categories.

questions.text: Which statement about neural networks is correct?
options: Neural networks can only process numerical data
Neural networks are inspired by biological neurons
Neural networks only work for image recognition
questions.correctAnswer: Neural networks are inspired by biological neurons
questions.explanation: Neural networks are computational models inspired by the structure and function of biological neural networks in animal brains.

exercises.title: Angular Memory Management
exercises.description: Understanding memory leaks in Angular applications
exercises.content: Memory leaks in Angular occur when subscriptions are not properly cleaned up.

questions.text: What is the recommended way to unsubscribe from Observables in Angular?
options: Never unsubscribe, Angular handles it automatically
Use the takeUntil operator with a Subject in ngOnDestroy
questions.correctAnswer: Use the takeUntil operator with a Subject in ngOnDestroy
questions.explanation: The takeUntil pattern with a Subject that completes in ngOnDestroy is a clean, maintainable way to manage multiple subscriptions. It ensures all subscriptions are properly cleaned up when the component is destroyed.

questions.text: Which Angular feature automatically handles subscription cleanup?
questions.explanation: The async pipe automatically subscribes to Observables and unsubscribes when the component is destroyed, eliminating the need for manual subscription management.

exercises.title: RAG Systems Architecture
exercises.content: RAG systems combine retrieval mechanisms with generative AI models.

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of RAG over pure generative models?
options: RAG reduces hallucinations by grounding responses in retrieved documents
questions.correctAnswer: RAG reduces hallucinations by grounding responses in retrieved documents
questions.explanation: RAG significantly reduces hallucinations (generation of plausible but incorrect information) by providing the model with relevant, factual context from a knowledge base before generating responses.

questions.text: Which technology is commonly used for similarity search in RAG systems?
options: Vector databases with embedding similarity search
questions.correctAnswer: Vector databases with embedding similarity search
questions.explanation: Vector databases (like FAISS, Pinecone, or Weaviate) enable efficient similarity search by comparing vector embeddings, which is essential for retrieving semantically relevant documents in RAG systems.

exercises.title: MLOps and CI/CD Pipelines
exercises.content: MLOps applies DevOps principles to machine learning workflows.

questions.text: What additional challenge does ML CI/CD face compared to traditional software CI/CD?
options: Data versioning and model performance tracking
questions.correctAnswer: Data versioning and model performance tracking
questions.explanation: Unlike traditional software, ML systems depend heavily on data and model performance. MLOps requires tracking data versions, model metrics, and detecting data/concept drift, which are unique challenges not present in traditional software CI/CD.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a model registry in MLOps?
options: To centrally manage and version trained models with metadata
questions.correctAnswer: To centrally manage and version trained models with metadata
questions.explanation: A model registry serves as a central repository for trained models, storing versions along with metadata like training parameters, performance metrics, and deployment history, enabling traceability and governance.

exercises.title: GDPR and Data Protection
exercises.content: GDPR regulates how organizations process personal data in the EU.

questions.text: Which GDPR principle requires collecting only necessary data?
questions.explanation: The data minimization principle requires that personal data be adequate, relevant, and limited to what is necessary for the purposes for which it is processed.

questions.text: What is the 'right to be forgotten' under GDPR?
options: The right to change your password
The right to request deletion of personal data
The right to encrypt your data
The right to access public databases
questions.correctAnswer: The right to request deletion of personal data
questions.explanation: The right to erasure (or 'right to be forgotten') allows individuals to request that organizations delete their personal data under certain conditions, such as when the data is no longer necessary for its original purpose.

exercises.title: Advanced Cybersecurity Concepts
exercises.description: Test your understanding of modern cybersecurity threats
exercises.content: Cybersecurity in the AI era requires understanding both defensive and offensive AI capabilities.

questions.text: What is an adversarial attack in the context of machine learning?
options: A DDoS attack on ML servers
Crafting inputs designed to cause ML models to make incorrect predictions
questions.correctAnswer: Crafting inputs designed to cause ML models to make incorrect predictions
questions.explanation: Adversarial attacks involve creating specially crafted inputs (adversarial examples) that cause machine learning models to make mistakes, often with imperceptible modifications to legitimate inputs.

questions.text: What does Zero Trust security architecture assume?
options: All internal network traffic is trustworthy
Never trust, always verify - no implicit trust for any entity
Trust is granted after initial authentication
questions.correctAnswer: Never trust, always verify - no implicit trust for any entity
questions.explanation: Zero Trust architecture operates on the principle that no user, device, or network should be trusted by default. Every access request must be verified regardless of whether it originates inside or outside the network perimeter.
